Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Walter Varhue of the University of Virginia to conduct a research project in Engineering during the summer of 2013 at Academia Sinica in Nangang District, Taipei City, Taiwan. The project title is "The Development of a Microfluidic Device for the Detection of Low Concentrations of Ribonucleic Acid Biomarkers." The host scientist is Professor Chiafu Chao.

This projected develops a microfluidic device for the sub pM amperometric detection of Ribonucleic acid biomarkers utilizing a redox cycle and a nano-slit platform. The use of a nano-slit platform for this device lowers the sample to answer assay time through the limitation of the potential diffusion lengths and the electro-kinetic pre-concentration of the target biomarker. The signal current produced by this device is also amplified through the use of a redox cycle. The integration of these techniques in a single device achieves a great improvement in the ability to detect biomarkers at a fM dilution. Furthermore, through device characterization, the diffusion of particles confined by nano-scale geometry and its effect on electro-chemical detection will be able to be studied. This improved detection ability will eventually allow for faster diagnosis of possible infections and easier detection of infectious materials in an environment. Its inclusion on a Lab-on-a-chip style microfluidic device will also allow for miniaturization of this process allowing for greater portability. The development of detection methods capable of discerning the viability, infectivity, and speciation of infectious micro-organisms is a healthcare priority for early diagnosis of infection and routine monitoring for infectious material. The device proposed in this research project will facilitate an improvement of such methods through the sub pM amperometric detection of Ribonucleic acid biomarkers. The use of such a proposed device will lead not only to greater ability to detect and diagnosis pathogens but also may lead to the miniaturization of such technologies. Portability will enable easier and faster detection of potential health hazards.

Broder impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this training will expand the Fellow's abilities as a teacher in the University of Virginias IC fabrication laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of improved methods for early diagnosis of infection and effective environmental monitoring for infectious materials is a major healthcare priority. To achieve this goal the development of sensor platforms capable of detecting the viability, infectivity, and speciation of pathogenic material is a necessity. As pathogens exhibit higher levels of Ribonucleic acid (mRNA) versus Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA), devices with moderate sensitivity in the fM to pM range of mRNA biomarkers could make a substantial contribution.[1] Currently a major limiting factor of sensor sensitivity at the sub pM range is the rapid degradation of mRNA levels after extraction from an infectious microorganism, which limits the maximum sample to assay time to less than 30 minutes. This project proposed to develop a device, which will improve the target detection sensitivity over that of traditional amperometric methods by reducing the assay time for mRNA and protein biomarkers, enhancing the detection signal for such biomarkers, and utilizing selective electorkinetic transport methods to rapidly pre-concentrate biomarkers at the sensors surface.

In order to improve over the sensitivity of standard amperometric methods the proposed device will utilize a Nano-gap electrode configuration. This configuration will utilize a pair of electrodes fabricated in a Nano depth fluidic channel (Nano-slit), spaced less than 100nm apart from one another.  This scheme would allow the use of a Redox cycling method which has been shown to amplify detection signal.[2] This configuration will also improve the poor diffusional transport typical of sub pM sample concentrations, as the Nano-scale geometries of the channel will limit potential diffusion lengths of target biomarkers. While the biomarkers in the Nano-depth channel will benefit from these limited diffusion lengths, biomarkers located in the bulk sample outside of the Nano-slit will still be affected by slower diffusion rates. The proposed device could overcome this limitation through the use of an electrokinetic transport methods to pre-concentrate the sample at the Nano-gap sensor region.[3]

As the scope of this entire project proved to be beyond the time allotted for the EAPSI program it was decided to focus primarily on only one aspect of this project during the two months. As the development of a method to facilitate large degrees of sample pre-concentration in a Nano-depth channel was seen as a logical first step, and because the host has had extensive experience and resources with which to pursue this aspect of the project, my time in Taiwan has mainly focused on attempting to demonstrate pre-concentration of fluorescently labeled particles within prefabricated Nano-depth quartz devices utilizing electrodeless dielectrophoreresis or EDEP.  EDEP utilizes the electrokinetic phenomena of dielectrophoresis (DEP) to exert a force on a polarized particle in a non-uniform AC electric field. As dielectrophoretic force is either directed towards or away from a high field point EDEP utilizes insulator geometries, such as constrictions, to generate controlled high and low field points where pre-concetration can occur. As the dimension of the insulating micro/nano fluidic channels can be used to influence the electric field in this way, such a method can be easily incorporated in or around the Nano-slip platform.[4]
